title: Carl Sawatski
text:
Carl Ernest Sawatski (November 4, 1927 – November 24, 1991) was an American <a href="professional%20baseball">professional baseball</a> <a href="baseball%20player">player</a> and executive. In the <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major Leagues</a>, he was a <a href="catcher">catcher</a> for the <a href="Chicago%20Cubs">Chicago Cubs</a> (1948, 1950 and 1953), <a href="Chicago%20White%20Sox">Chicago White Sox</a> (1954), <a href="Atlanta%20Braves%23Milwaukee%20%281953%E2%80%931965%29">Milwaukee Braves</a> (1957–58), <a href="Philadelphia%20Phillies">Philadelphia Phillies</a> (1958–59) and <a href="St.%20Louis%20Cardinals">St. Louis Cardinals</a> (1960–63). He also was an influential figure in <a href="minor%20league%20baseball">minor league baseball</a>.
Sawatski attended <a href="Pompton%20Lakes%20High%20School">Pompton Lakes High School</a> in <a href="Pompton%20Lakes%2C%20New%20Jersey">Pompton Lakes, New Jersey</a>, where he played football and basketball, in addition to baseball.
A left-handed batter who threw right-handed, Sawatski the player stood (178 cm) tall and weighed 210 pounds (95 kg). The native of <a href="Shickshinny%2C%20Pennsylvania">Shickshinny, Pennsylvania</a>, played 11 seasons in MLB, appearing in 633 <a href="games%20played">games</a>. His career totals include 1,449 <a href="at%20bats">at bats</a>, 133 <a href="run%20%28baseball%29">runs</a>, 351 <a href="Hit%20%28baseball%29">hits</a>, 46 <a href="double%20%28baseball%29">doubles</a>, five <a href="triple%20%28baseball%29">triples</a>, 58 <a href="home%20runs">home runs</a>, 213 <a href="runs%20batted%20in">runs batted in</a>, two <a href="stolen%20bases">stolen bases</a> and 191 <a href="Base%20on%20balls">walks</a>, and <a href="batting%20average%20%28baseball%29">batted</a> .242.
Sawatski helped the Braves win the <a href="National%20League">National League</a> <a href="pennant%20%28sports%29">pennant</a>, appearing in 58 games, 19 as a catcher (third-most among the club's backstops), and contributing six home runs to the Milwaukee cause. During the <a href="1957%20World%20Series">1957 World Series</a> against the <a href="New%20York%20Yankees">New York Yankees</a>, Sawatski had two appearances as a <a href="pinch%20hitter">pinch hitter</a> (Games 3 and 6) and <a href="strikeout">struck out</a> each time, but the Braves prevailed in seven games to win the world title.
Sawatski was a prodigious minor league hitter. He batted .352 and slugged 34 homers in the Class D <a href="North%20Atlantic%20League">North Atlantic League</a> in 1947. Then, two seasons later, he led the <a href="Double-A%20%28baseball%29">Double-A</a> <a href="Southern%20Association">Southern Association</a> with 45 homers and batted .360, second in the league. After his playing career ended, Sawatski served as the <a href="general%20manager%20%28baseball%29">general manager</a> of the <a href="Arkansas%20Travelers">Arkansas Travelers</a> of the Double-A <a href="Texas%20League">Texas League</a>, a Cardinal affiliate, from 1967–75. He then was elected president of the Texas League itself and served in the post from 1976 until his 1991 death in <a href="Little%20Rock%2C%20Arkansas">Little Rock</a> at the age of 64. During his presidency, the league prospered as part of the renaissance of minor league baseball that began in the 1980s.
